awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Satellites in Low Earth Orbit as a Learning Tool
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to support development of a Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) workforce. With the recent successes of space missions to other planets, space-based STEM learning tools will attract the attention of teachers, students, parents, and the public.  This project proposes a system to teach middle-school students about analysis, design, building and testing of small satellites. The system uses space-based systems as a compelling context to teach STEM concepts and methods. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project creates STEM insights using a satellite as the context.  For instance, a major challenge is accommodating the payload into a small stowed volume.  Miniaturization is sometimes a solution but may be limited by the physics.  For example, if a communications antenna exceeding the satellite size is desired, it must initially stow into a volume only on the order of a 10 cm cube.  Following stowage, it must be deployed on orbit reliably and with an accurate and precise shape.  The proposed lesson plan includes: preliminary concept design of a student-accessible small satellite, a teacher and student step-by-step lessons workbook on introductory remote sensing from space, physics of satellite orbits, and detailed software specifications to use gaming approaches for educational plans.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Phase I project from the NSF, enabled the achievement of our technical objectives.  We completed the creation of three STEM-centric lesson plans designed to simulate remote sensing data from satellites flying in low earth orbit.  The lessons have been pilot-tested in several schools and received very positive feedback from teachers.  The lessons are designed to have a fun factor and to help the student realize that STEM involves only simple logical steps in the understanding of natural phenomena.  Lessons are designed, keyed to actual data derived from orbiting satellites such as close-to-real time live images and videos of the ice sheets, study of forest fire regimes, infrared images of rainforests and sunspot activities correlated with auroral activity, etc.  In the near future, actual satellite-derived images and video data will be made accessible to the students for study in the comfort of their classrooms. The students also learn the use of GIS (Geographic Information Software) and similar tools to analyze the remotely sensed information.

             The Phase I funding further enabled the creation of the preliminary requirements for a small CubeSat-size satellite, the completion of a mid to high school level textbook on Understanding Satellites and Orbits, and the creation of a top-level outline of the Teacher's and Student's Manual.  All of these are geared towards making STEM learning fun and easier to follow and understand.  This is the first step in creating our commercial product.  We have also completed the preliminary software specifications for a STEM In-Space Video Game software.  As there are tens of thousands of secondary educational institutions in the U.S. alone and more than a million more around the world, we have a rich and expanding customer base.  Our market opportunity will increase as we make the video game software available to the public. This will promote STEM and STEM education and will increase advocacy.  We are extensively promoting our products to the U.S. local and national market.  Also, as a result of our initial marketing activities, we were invited and presented our NSF-sponsored project at the 2022 Innovation Summit in the Philippines that resulted in the signing of memoranda of understanding with two Philippine Schools to conduct Pilot Studies and make our products available in the area.  Three more schools have expressed interest in our offerings.

The preliminary requirements for a small STEM Satellite were generated noting the main challenge that must be overcome; namely, enabling the payload to fit within the small confines of the available stowage volume.  The approach was to design packageable-deployable solutions like that used in the James Webb Space Telescope where a very large telescope primary could be packaged into a volume one tenth its final deployed size.  To achieve efficient stowage, foldable shape-memory composite material was used in the design.  This enables the stowage of payloads up to twelve times larger in size than the STEM Satellite. In particular, a 40-centimeter diameter parabolic dish antenna and a pair of two-meter-long shape memory booms to measure the electric field at altitude, were determined to be stowable into one quarter of the total satellite volume, including a small medium resolution camera.  The Phase I project also resulted in the invention and patent application filing for a CubeSat-based near zero coefficient of thermal expansion parabolic dish antenna.

We are convinced that when kids start looking up to scientists and engineers like they do to star athletes and mega-celebrities, society will undergo a rapid positive transformation never before seen.
